Definition: Piecewise clarity; components are visibly separated for readability.
When to use: Emphasizes clarity of separate parts or '+' being clearer.
When not to use: If the point is speed/cognitive effort without parts clarity.
Example quote: I found that is was more clear and I didn't have to think as hard.
For example- print(f"Hello {name}, sup?") Many editors like VS Code would highlight "{name}" in a different color, making it more intuitive to understand that it's a variable to be plugged

Definition: Fewer tokens/joins; shorter, more concise expression.
When not to use: If the text is about error risk only.
Example quote: Interpolation made it very clear where whitespace is preserved, even though it might be slightly more verbose.

Definition: Simpler or more recognizable placeholder markers/syntax.
When not to use: If clarity refers only to IDE coloring.
Example quote: I find string concatenation more readable because it naturally causes a separation between parts of the string using the + symbol and spaces.

Definition: Readable at first glance without detailed parsing.
When not to use: If timing refers to debugging, not reading.
Example quote: I found string concatenation more readable as I found hat I was able to piece together the pieces faster.

Definition: Sentence-like flow that reads naturally without mental reordering.
When not to use: If claim is about traceability, not flow.
Example quote: To compound, the idea of addition is also more natural than substitution when combining literals together - for me at least.

Definition: Simpler or more recognizable placeholder markers/syntax.
When not to use: If clarity refers only to IDE coloring.
Example quote: When using the + symbol, I would often find myself confusing it with addition.

When not to use: If a clear preference is stated.
Example quote: However, interpolation seems like it would make for more readable code in the more meaningful context.

Definition: Piecewise clarity; components are visibly separated for readability.
When to use: Emphasizes clarity of separate parts or '+' being clearer.
When not to use: If the point is speed/cognitive effort without parts clarity.
Example quote: I felt that string interpolation was more readable because when reading a string, it was much clearer that the curly brackets were not part of the string.

Definition: Readable at first glance without detailed parsing.
When not to use: If timing refers to debugging, not reading.
Example quote: concatenation, I am not familiar with interpolation but inferred what I could however if I was familiar, the flow of something like {a}{b}{c} is much faster to understand than a+b+c

Definition: Reduced visual noise compared to '+' concatenation; cleaner, more compact lines.
When not to use: If only speed or debugging is discussed.
Example quote: Interpolation reduces the visual clutter of multiple + operators and quotes, especially in longer strings.
With concatenation there is always a pause in the string and this makes it harder to understand how the formatting of the string is written.

Definition: Sentence-like flow that reads naturally without mental reordering.
When not to use: If claim is about traceability, not flow.
Example quote: It was easier to logically place into the sentence and visualize it.

Definition: Perceived wordiness or excessive length that hinders readability.
When to use: Calls one form wordy/lengthy to read.
When not to use: If verbosity refers to writing, not reading.
Example quote: What I mean is it was hard to read concatenation when it was just seemingly random letters/numbers, but when it was within the URLs it made a lot more sense
